title: Soroban for Special Needs Students: Adaptations and Benefits
description: How soroban can work for children with learning differences, ADHD, dyslexia, and autism.
imageAlt: Child with special needs using soroban successfully

content.intro: Soroban isn't just for "typical" learners. Its visual, tactile, systematic nature makes it uniquely suited for many children with learning differences.

sections.text: Why Soroban Often Works for Special Needs

items: Systematic: Same process every time, predictable

sections.text: Many children with ADHD struggle with traditional math because it's passive and abstract. Soroban offers:
For ADHD: Keep sessions very short (5 minutes), allow standing/movement, use speed challenges to channel hyperactivity positively.
Children with dyslexia often have trouble with:

items: Beads are physical, not confusable symbols
Process is always the same sequence
No need to hold numbers in mind – they're visible on the beads

sections.text: Many autistic children excel with soroban because of:

items: Pattern recognition: Many autistic minds excel here
Individual: No social demands during practice

sections.text: Some of the top mental calculation champions are on the autism spectrum. The systematic nature of soroban aligns with how many autistic minds process information.

rows: Larger soroban, larger beads, or digital app
Wooden beads (not plastic click), quiet space
No timers, unlimited time, celebration of completion not speed
Visual checklists, same routine every time
Preview what's coming, no surprises, private practice

When Soroban May NOT Be Ideal
Honest assessment – soroban isn't for everyone:

items: Severe fine motor impairment (try digital alternatives)
Very severe intellectual disability (may need simpler approaches)
Strong aversion to repetitive tasks (core requirement of soroban)

sections.text: But don't assume – try before deciding it won't work.

faq.question: Should I tell the child they're doing soroban because of their diagnosis?
faq.answer: No need. Present it as a fun way to learn math. The method helps everyone – the child doesn't need to know why you chose it.

faq.question: What if traditional soroban centers won't accommodate my child?
faq.answer: Home-based learning with apps may work better. Self-paced, no social pressure, adaptable to your child's needs.

faq.question: Will soroban "cure" my child's learning difference?
faq.answer: No – but it can work around it. The goal isn't to fix the child, it's to find an approach that works for their brain.

cta.text: SoroKid's self-paced, visual learning works well for diverse learners.
